title: Cat. 35  Denarius (Coin) Portraying Emperor Augustus, 19/18 B.C.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Denarius (Coin) Portraying Emperor Augustus  
19/18 B.C., issued by Augustus  
Silver; diam. 2 cm; 3.90 g  
Mint: Spain, possibly Colonia Caesaraugusta (Zaragoza) or Colonia Patricia (Cordoba)  
Obverse: Head of Augustus left, civic oak crown  
Inscribed: CAESAR AVGVSTVS (outward)  
Reverse: Comet  
Inscribed: DIVVS IVLIVS (across)  
RIC I 37b; BMCRE I 326; axis: 6:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4856

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The coinage of this period lets us observe the experiments in political ideology that transmuted the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire. In January 27 B.C., the Senate voted Octavian Caesar two titles that changed the face of government in Rome: Princeps (the first head) and Augustus (the revered one). Princeps gives us a designation for this period of Roman history, the Principate, as well as the origin of our word prince. Augustus became Octavian’s legal and preferred cognomen. Added to his adoptive father’s name, Caesar, it gave him a new way to present himself to the world, as he does on this coin. Both Caesar and Augustus would continue to be used as titles for future emperors for as long as Rome survived.

Among the other honors the Senate granted Octavian at the same time was the right to wear the civic oak wreath (corona civica). This was traditionally awarded to a citizen who had saved the life of another Roman on the battlefield; Octavian, they decreed, had saved all Roman citizens by his victory at Actium. Images of Augustus with the oak wreath were typical on coin issues from Rome and Spain. The left-facing portrait reminds us that die-cutters could work from either side of the “official” sculpted portrait of Augustus, crowned with the oak wreath. This portrait type survives today in more than 150 extant examples, as well as on the magnificent Gemma Augustea (fig. 35.1).

The comet on the reverse, with the inscription “divine Julius,” refers to the apotheosis of Octavian’s adoptive father. Julius Caesar had been deified by vote of the Senate on January 1, 42 B.C., an action that the Roman populace believed was confirmed by the appearance for seven days of a comet over Rome during Caesar’s funeral games two years later. Stars had been associated with Julius Caesar even during his lifetime, evidently due to Caesar’s ancestry through Venus, the evening star (fig. 35.2); and were subsequently used on coins of the triumvirs to declare their caesarian allegiance. This coin is the earliest appearance of a “hairy star” (sidus crinitum), or comet, perhaps referring directly to the “renewal of interest in the nature, origin, and future of Augustus’s reign.”

Taken individually, these titles and images are all traditional, even conservative. But taken together, the associations hinted at divinity: even the civic crown was a reminder of the tree sacred to Jupiter, who often wore an oak wreath.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">BMCRE I, p. lxiv; also see Zanker, Power of Images, p. 93.

The “official” portrait is represented by the Augustus Bevilacqua bust in the Glyptothek München, Munich, acc. no. 317.

John T. Ramsey and A. Lewis Licht have conclusively confirmed the comet’s existence; Ramsey and Licht, Comet of 44 B.C. See also Pliny, Natural History 2.23.94; Suetonius, Julius Caesar, sec. 88.
